title: Stepping feet« illusion 1 – strong
summary: Observe the movement of blue and yellow “feet”. The feet seem to step alternately, like tiny feet going tip-tap-tip-tap… This is more pronounced if you do not look directly on the feet, but between them. In reality their movement is always simultaneous.

title: Motion Aftereffect – also known as »waterfall effect«
summary: Fixate on the central cross during the motion. Observe the motion aftereffect in the resting figure (the Buddha of Kamakura). The “warping” caused by the motion aftereffect applies to anything you look at.

title: Reverse Phi Motion – something for the specialist
summary: There is a movie in which something looks like moving but does not in fact.

title: »Rotating Snakes« Illusion – with a new explanatory twist
summary: The image demonstrates strong rotation of the “wheels”, occurring in relation to eye movements. On steady fixation the effect vanishes.

title: Snake ad lib – optimising this motion illusion
summary: The pattern at the right is stationary – yet it seems to expand, especially if you don’t look directly at it, for instance when reading this text.

title: “Rotating Snakes” – with luminance control
summary: When looking around the above static image you might see illusory rotation.

title: Motion Induced Blindness – an illusion of disappearing dots
summary: Stare at the flashing dot in the center and then the yellow spots disappear once in a while.

title: Stereokinetic Phenomenon – an optical illusion of 3D from motion (aka »kinetic depth effect«)
summary: Rotation of adequate figures creates a three-dimensional illusion.

title: Motion silences hue changes – winner of the illusion contest 2011
summary: It is hard to perceive the color change during the rotation.

title: Pinna-Brelstaff Illusion
summary: Fixate the blue cross in the centre. While the shrinking/expanding goes on, note that the rings subtly rotate relative to each other. But they are not really rotating!

title: Pinna-Brelstaff Illusion № 2
summary: Stare at the moving red dot and the squares seem to shift.

title: Kinegram (“Scanimation”) – akin to a flip book
summary: A black grating with narrow slits moves to and fro. Partially covered by it, there are blue balls eaten by the pac-man at the left.

title: Roget's Palisade Illusion
summary: We can see 2 major items: a reddish picket fence (a “palisade”) is moving, partially obscuring a black spoke wheel that rotates.The interesting thing: the spokes seem bent in the bottom half of the wheel!

title: Spoke Illusion – a motion illusion + an unexpected (?) aftereffect
summary: It seems that the wheel defined by the dark-bright sectors is rotating counter-clockwise and the spokes are rotating clockwise. In fact, the spokes stay put!

title: Wagon-wheel effect – closely related to stroboscopic artifacts
summary: As the rotations per minute of the wheel increasing, it looks rotating faster in the beginning. Then it looks like getting slower and even stand still. Finally, it seems to rotate reverse.

title: Wagon-wheel with colours
summary: Since our brain associates each new position with the closest preceding one, we see a counter-clockwise rotation.

title: Stroboscopic Artifacts – making a teaching point out of a nuisance
gifFileName: Stroboscopic Artifacts – making a teaching point out of a nuisance.gif
summary: Spinning the wheel faster produces color mixture and at some times we can see the wheel spin backwards, but it spins in the same direction all the time

title: Sigma Motion – an optical illusion due to an interaction of image dynamics and eye movements
summary: Following the mouse with your gaze. You will see smooth rightwards motion first than the leftwards motion of the stripes.

title: Spine Drift illusion – more on eye movements
summary: As the picture moving (you can even shake your head or display), the cetral square seems to float.

title: Eye Jitter – and even more on involuntary eye movements
summary: When you shake your head  the display rapidly, a central disk will segregate as a distinct object, which in addition seems to be floating atop the background.

title: Biological Motion – for me the most beautiful class of visual illusions
gifFileName: Biological Motion – for me the most beautiful class of visual illusions.gif
summary: The white dots on black background in the neighbouring image do not seem to form any recognizable Gestalt. However, as soon as the movie starts, a vivid figure emerges.

title: Flash-lag Effect – moving and stationary objects perceived at different times
summary: The flashing line seem to have a different angle. In fact the two lines align perfectly.

title: Ramp Aftereffect – an aftereffect in time
summary: Stare at the cental cross for a while (at least 10 seconds) and you will see the appearent dimming and brightening for a few seconds on steady grey image.

title: Enigma (Isia Leviant)
summary: Stare at the centre of the figure for a while. Some ‘scintillating’ activity will build up in the violet and blueish annuli. Some observers also report a circular rotation within these regions; things will begin to “run around in circles”.

title: Freezing Rotation Illusion – a “Best Illusion of the Year” winner
summary: In the demo you see (1) an inner rotating part (the text) placed on (2) a rotating disk made up of coloured dots. The outer disk does not rotate continuously, but ‘swings’ back and forth. What is the motion of the central text? Is is a smooth rotation? Or doesn’t it rather ‘freeze’ now and then, depending on the outer rotation?

title: »Stepping feet« illusion 2 – circular version of »Stepping feet 1«
summary: The yellow and blue ‘feet’ seem to alternatingly overtake each other. In reality, the feet are moving fully in parallel.

title: Motion Binding
summary: The blue lines look like moving in pairs but they are 4 sides of a same square.

title: Tusi Motion
summary: All single discs move in straight lines, but our visual system combines their composite motion into the gestalt of a wheel.

title: Breathing Square
summary: Start by watching the demonstration. In particular, track the blue shape obscured by the orange squares. After one cycle you know that there is a blue square of constant size which slowly rotates. But to nearly every observer it looks like the square is changing its size, “breathing” so to speak.

title: Missing-fundamental motion inversion
summary: The top one move to the left, no doubt, but the bottom one looks like it’s moving to the right. While if you follow the contours (e.g. using your finger), you will notice this really also moves leftwards.

title: »Kaleidoscope Motion« Illusion
summary: Physically, the rotation is perfectly smooth. However it seemingly jolts ever so often.

title: Ternus Display
summary: Although only the dots on the left and right are blinking, we would perceive these dots as a group moving back and forth.

title: Stroboscopic alternative motion
summary: There are actually 4 discs staying put, just their visibility is switched. The grouping to horizontal, vertical or rotatory motion occurs in our brain.

title: “Pigeon Neck” illusion
summary: The pigeons seem to crane their neck and the worms look like shrinking and extending.

title: “Psychokinematic” objects
summary: Rotation of adequate figures creates a three-dimensional illusion.

title: Spiral Motion Aftereffect – more effective for some
summary: Gaze at the center of the rotating spiral for about 20 seconds, then look elsewhere. You will notice that whatever you look at now appears swirling.

title: Hermann’s Grid – fleeting luminance illusions
summary: Dark patches appear in the “street crossings”, except the ones which you are directly looking at.

title: Hermann’s Grid bent – a new twist
summary: When the grid lines are straight, dark patches appear in the street crossings, except the ones which you are directly looking at. When the streets are curving, the dark patches vanish.

title: Scintillating Grid – strong fleeting luminance illusions
summary: There are black spots appearing and disappearing at the cross where you are not looking at.

title: 12 Vanishing Dots – No variation of the above
summary: There are 12 black dots in the above picture, but one can’t see them all at the same time.

title: Translational Moiré Patterns
summary: In the adjacent animation you see two pairs of concentric ring arrays. The blue one moves a little, and the superposition of the blue rings with the green background rings creates curved dark bands. These are known as “moirés” (French).

title: Rotatory Moiré Patterns
summary: A self-organising structure appears, circles at various sizes, squares, crosses, etc, which dynamically change while you observe them

title: Pulfrich effect – luminance turning time into displacement → stereo
summary: The blur spots looks far than the clear spots.

title: Classic simultaneous brightness contrast probed
summary: The brightness of the two squares seem different due to the effect of the background. In fact, they are identical.

title: Induced grating – classic brightness contrast
summary: Above you see a so-called luminance grating with 4 dark-bright cycles. In the middle there is a horizontal greyish bar. Is the lightness (grey tone) constant when gazing along it? You may observe that the grey in the stripe is slightly darker and brighter along its length, in counterphase to the grating.

title: Shaded-diamond illusion – more brightness contrast
summary: The diamonds at the bottom of the entire pyramid look darker. In fact, all diamonds are identical.

title: Craik-O’Brien-Cornsweet – collaboration of retina & cortex
summary: The color of the center of the left dish is the same as that of the background and the color of the right dish is darker than the left dish and background. However, the left dish looks darker when the yellow ring is covering neither the left dish nor the right dish, and the color of all three looks the same when the yellow ring is covering either the left dish or the right dish.

title: Wertheimer-Koffka-Ring – pitting Gestalt vs. lateral inhibition
summary: Compare the two halves of the ring. The left half looks subtly darker than the right one. In fact, they are identical.

title: Mach Bands
summary: There is a dark area and a light area, the gap filled by a luminance ramp. The luminance ramp goes up, and then stays constant (visible in the green profile). The visual impression, however, is a bright band a the right end of the ramp, and a darkish band a the left end of the ramp.

title: Simultaneous Contrast – here dynamic
summary: There are two disks, pulsating between dark and light. If it is light, the two disks are in synchrony. However, when one background is dark and the other light, they pulsate with opposite phase.

title: Pyramid Illusion – Vasarely revealed
summary: As the number of layers increasing, the corners seem to form lines.

title: Munker-White Illusion – contrary to lateral inhibition
summary: The brightness will change when the black grating is moved away from the green bars.

title: Adelson’s »Corrugated Plaid« – context affecting brightness
summary: Compare the top and bottom gray squares for their brightness. They appear (and, indeed, physically are) equal.

title: Adelson’s »Checker Shadow« illusion – more context affecting brightness
summary: Square B looks brighter, while Square A and B are identical.

title: Contour Adaptation – a new case of contrast gain control
summary: Keep your gaze steadily on the green cross in the center. When the flicker stops, the wheels are gone – only to reappear after a few seconds.

title: Contrast Constancy – demonstrating space-average-based contrast gain control
summary: With the outer checkboards, two inner checkboards seem to be diiferent, but in fact they are the same.

title: Contrast Gain Control – demonstrating temporal contrast gain control
summary: Gaze for a few seconds at the fixation cross in the centre of the neighbouring image pair. After the change, on the left part you will (initially) perceive high contrast, on the right markedly less contrast. Although they are identical.

title: Lazy Shadow – Interaction of luminance & time
summary: When the layerd and aligned shapes that are ordered according to their luminace are rotating with a same speed, they look misaligned.

title: Grid Masking – What hides behind the grating?
summary: Here is a grating, or a grid. But there is something hidden in it. Shaking the picture make the hidden thing more visable.

title: »Shape from shading« – strong
summary: In the beginning there is a dent at middle bottom. But after it has rotated to the bottom, it has mutated to a bump, and all other bumps to dents!

title: Hinton's »Lilac Chaser« – a strong aftereffect
summary: You see a circle of blue-violettish (=magenta) blobs, one of which briefly disappears, circling around. Let your gaze rest on the central fixation cross, but observe with your “inner eye” the patches just when they disappear. With good fixation, you should see a strong greenish colour whenever the violet patch has disappeared.

title: Watercolor Illusion – long-range colour induction
summary: You may see that the diagonal squares are subtly colored in orange-ish. In fact, all squares have a totally white background.

title: chromostereopsis demonstration
summary: The brighter (in luminace, here red) looks closer.

title: Context affects colour – different eyes?
summary: You may feel that the left eye has a blueish tint, while the one on the right has a neutral gray. In fact, they are identical.

title: Colour Fan – more aftereffects
summary: Initially, a red “fan” rotates over a green background – obviously. Now gaze steadily on the central fixation targe; let your gaze hang, so to speak. After a few seconds you will notice: the green under the fan is greener than on the surrounding ring, and the red fan blades are redder then the central red disk which turns slightly greyish.

title: Benham’s Top – colour from spatio-temporal patterns
summary: Although the display is just black–grey–white, a suitable temporal modulation of local patterns makes us see colour.

title: Benham’s Top “unrolled”
summary: The upper stripes look reddish, the middle ones look greenish, and the bottom ones look blueish.

title: Colour Assimilation
summary: When covered by parts of the background grid, left disk seems having a strong cyan tint, the middle one magenta, the right one yellow. Actually, all three are light yellow!

title: Neon Colour Spreading
summary: On the right, black lines flank a green star. This star sports a “neon glow” around it, so it looks a little like a green disk.

title: White (?) Xmas – a seasonal variant of White's illusion
summary: The two trees are absolutely identical in their colour, while the left one looks a little more yellowish.

title: Munker Illusion
summary: The two colors look different with different surroundings but they are the same.

title: Structure from motion – fails at equiluminance
summary: You will see a swarm of red moving disks. On closer inspection they organise themselves into a rotating sphere. This sphere may rotate left- or rightwards, and may even switch spontaneously

title: Loss of countour in colour
summary: While you are watching, the luminance of the green disks varies from “darker than red” to “brighther than red”. In beetween it passes “equiluminance” where the two only differ in colour, not in luminance. Interestingly, in “equiluminance”, contour completion breaks down.

title: Gestalt loss in equilumance
summary: When the brightness of fore- and background is identical, the gestalt becomes ill-defined, it loses cohesion.

title: Equiluminance – Heterochromatic flicker fusion & minimum motion
summary: If two colors flicker very fast, it looks like the birghter one.

title: Colour Phi
summary: You will see movement from the left to the right and may also observe the colour change “along the way”, e.g. at midpoint. Actually, it just that the red disk on the left disappears, and the blue disk on the right reappears after a brief interval.

title: Dress Color enigma
summary: This is a social illusion. Some people see a gold/white dress while the others see a black/blue dress.

title: Red Strawberries that are not red – strong demo of colour constancy
summary: In fact, there is not a single pixel that’s red here, or even reddish. If the image is masked, leaving only what for me were some of the reddest parts, the seeming red (mostly) disappears.

title: McCollough Effect – an aftereffect that can last months
summary: You will now see coloured stripes, two sets, alternating every 2 seconds. This needs to be viewed for 2–5 minutes. Then see the black and white stripes. Now you will see faint colours in the pattern that has been black and white before.

title: Color Change illusion through eye movements
gifFileName: Color Change Illusion by eye movement.gif
summary: In this illusion, either downward or rightward motion perception for the dots is possible. Depending on the perceived motion direction, color changes: red and green dots with downward motion, and yellow dots with rightward motion.

title: Skye’s Oblique Grating – No Café Wall variant
summary: The blue horizontal stripes seem to be oblique. But they are actually parallel.

title: Oblique Grating adjustable
summary: The blue horizontal stripes above are oblique, while they are parallel in reality.

title: Tilted Table – a cute Zöllner variant
summary: The two rectangles are parallel to each other but the stripe makes them look tilted.

title: Hering Illusion – and other angular interactions
summary: When the oblique lines disappear, it revealing the fact that the red bars were completely straight all the time.

title: Poggendorff Illusion – a classical geometric optical illusion with a new twist
summary: The two ends of a straight line segment passing behind an obscuring rectangle appear offset when, in fact, they are aligned.

title: Disjointed Arch Illusion – a strong Poggendorff variant
summary: It seems that the two stone arcs going up behind the vertical gray bar are not going to meet at the top. Actually, they will meet.

title: Fraser’s Spiral
summary: The picture looks like spirals but it is formed with no spirals.

title: Tilt Illusion
summary: The demonstration is set up to allow quantitative measurements on the strength of the illusion depending on the angle disparity of the background gratings.

title: »Café Wall« Illusion
summary: Above, the tiles are moving left and right in alternating rows. In the ‘half-shifted condition’, the ‘mortar lines’; (the horizontal lines between the tiles) appear to slope alternately upward and downward. This gives the impression that the tiles are wedge-shaped. As seen when the tiles align or make up a chequerboard, the lines are actually parallel, and all tiles are perfectly square and of the same size. So during the movement, the illusion “comes and goes”.

title: Triangle Puzzle – a puzzle
summary: Three pieces move to another place, the overall shape seems the same, but the square is no longer missing.

title: Checker Bulge
summary: The checkerboard seems to distort with the dot.

title: Jastrow Illusion – a classic
summary: It looks like the lower track is larger. In fact, they are identical.

title: Müller-Lyer Illusion – test your bisection accuracy
summary: The line are separated by the arrow, the two sides of line seem to have the same length. But actually they are not.

title: Moon illusion
summary: There are two size of the moon in the picture.  Given the perspective of the scene, the smaller one seems not the correct size, while it is actually.

title: T-illusion
summary: For any two lines perpendicular to each other, the vertical one looks longer than the horizontal one.

title: Sine Illusion
summary: All bars look not alike in height. While all of them have the same height.

title: Schäffel's Luminance Looming
summary: Observe the animation. Does it appear to ‘breathe’ in for 3 seconds, out for 3 seconds? Does it alternatingly move towards you (“loom”) and recede? This illusion of motion in depth can be enhanced by observing with one eye only. Also it seems stronger with a little blur.

title: Shepard’s “Turning the Tables”
summary: The two table tops certainly do not look alike. While it does.

title: Shepard’s “Subterranean Terror”
summary: The size of same image looks different with different surroundings.

title: Reverspective – reverse perspective
summary: It seems like 3 corridors leading into the depth, and the entire arrangement rotates a little. In reality, the depth is inverted.

title: Necker Cube – the mother of reversible figures
summary: If you view the cube for a prolonged time, you may perceive sudden perceptual reversal (typically every 3–5 s) between the two cube orientations as depicted.

title: Missing Corner Cube – a cube with multiple ambiguities
summary: You might see different situations. First, it is a cube, but one corner is missing. Second, there is a smaller cube attached to the corner, in front of the larger cube – and it rotates inversely to the large cube. Third, imagine you’re looking at a room corner, and a cube is placed in that corner.

title: Ames Window
summary: The fence seems to reverse the rotation direction with the ballerina passing through the fence. In fact, this effect happens because of the distorted fence.

title: Ambiguous Silhouette Illusion
summary: You will see the silhouette of a spinning figurine. Some may think that she spin clockwise, but other may think she spin counterclockwise.

title: Anamorphosis
summary: Holbein painted the shape with a strong perspective distortion. You could try a slanting look on the image from top right. This allows you to make the shape recognisable.

title: Leaning Towers Illusion
summary: The towers do not seem to be parallel but they are the same.

title: Blind Spot – intelligent fill-in
summary: Close your left eye. You will partially see your nose, that’s the blob on the lower left. You will, of course, not actually see your eyebrows “from within”, that’s artistic freedom from Ernst Mach, on whose beautiful drawing the present demonstration is based. Fully stretch out your left arm, make a partial fist, index finger pointing straight up, thumb pointing straight to the right. Fixate the top of your index finger (indicated by the bull’s eye). Fully stretch out your right arm, shape like for the left hand. Let your thumbs just touch, and wiggle your right index finger a little (arrows). Keep your gaze on the top of the left index finger, but with your “inner eye” observe the top of the right index finger – don’t directly look at it, keep your gaze steadily on the left index finger (the one with the bull’s eye). Your right index finger should seem to vanish at its top.

title: Darwin Illusion – the afterimage creates a recognisable Gestalt
summary: Gaze the tiny red target at the picture's centre for at least 10 seconds and then close your eyes. After a few seconds a face will appear.

title: Blur & picture content – spatial filtering (or high frequency masking)
summary: The same image has different explanations with or without blur.

title: Hidden message – blur & figure-ground discrimination
summary: Blurring the image reveals an unexpected message of doubtful soundness.

title: Kanizsa’s Triangle – depends on context
summary: We can perceive that there is a triangle inside the "Pack-people". However, when the "Pack-people" go inside, the triangle disappears.

title: Blotted letters – Gestalt completion
summary: These look like random shapes until the ink covers part of them.

title: Hidden Figure – Dalmatian Dog with 2 helpers
summary: There is a Dalmatian dog in the picture. If you do not aware of it, the image looks like black patches on a white background. However, once you see the dog, you will always aware of it (one-shot learning).

title: Hidden Bird – more camouflage
summary: bove you see a “bird” moving over a background of random scrambles. The bird will stop and merge with the background.

title: Hidden object in brick wall
summary: There is a brick wall, but actually there is an object hidding in the picture. After finding it once, you cannot ignore it.

title: Rotation – changes the interpretation
summary: Some things change completely when turned upside down.

title: Impossible Objects – draw your own impossible object
summary: Our brain constructing a 3D world based on the flat image results in an impossible object.

title: Hallucii – An “impossible” movie
summary: With the special camera perspective, the floor seems having an infinite loop. Movie directed & created by Goo-Shun Wang.

title: Impossible waterfall – Another Escher inspiration
summary: If you watch this movie, you will see water running upwards and driving a water mill.

title: Numerosity adaptation
summary: When the blobs are colored, there are many on the left, few on the right. When the blobs are grey, there seems to have more blobs on the right. Actually, they are equally distributed.

title: Delboeuf Illusion – with an application to eating
summary: The loose border makes the same object look smaller.

title: Ebbinghaus Illusion
summary: You’ll notice a ring of large blueish disks and a ring of small blueish disks. The two orange circles seem in different size. In reality, they have the same size.

title: Dynamic Ebbinghaus Illusion
summary: You see the the orange disk as smaller when it’s in the middle, and growing larger when moving to the bottom right. The effect increases when you fixate the blue dot on the top left blue disk. But the orange disk is not changed at all.

title: Rotating face mask – hollow faces
summary: These are rotating face masks. Note that the ‘hollow’; (negative) version of the face immediately switches back into a positive view, one cannot ‘hold’; it.

title: Find the Face (in the Beans) – a picture puzzle
gifFileName: Find the Face in the Beans.gif
summary: You may find the face among the beans.

title: The face on Mars – imaginations of perception
summary: The picture looks like a face

title: Church or chicken?
summary: You may see a chicken looking at you. While it is a church.

title: The »Thatcher Illusion« – inverted faces lose their emotional message
summary: We can not perceive that the right face's mouth and eyes are actually upside down.

title: »Ghostly Gaze« Illusion
summary: The ladies look to the left or right when the images are blurred, while actually, they look straight to you.

title: Dr. Angry and Mr. Smile – two messages in two spatial frequency bands
summary: The image slowly changes between sharp and blurred. When it is sharp, the face on the left looks angry and male and the right one looks kind and female. With increasing blur the expressions swap.

title: The Lincoln Effect
summary: The image is just a number of brownish blocks at first time. Finer the image then it becomes recognisable via blurring.

title: 3D Schröder Staircase
summary: A traditional Schröder staircase is a 2D picture having two interpretation, a staircase seen from above and that seen from below, and the second interpretation can be perceived easily if we turn the picture upside-down. The present 3D object also has two interpretations, both of which are staircases seen from above, and the interpretations switch from one to the other when we rotate the object by 180 degrees around the vertical axis.

title: The Real Thing??
summary: The video shows a  illusion of perceiving a reflection of a coke can in a mirror. While it is not a mirror in reality.

title: Landloping ladybugs: Frame-induced position shift
summary: One bug seems to flash on the left and the other on the right—although they’re really aligned one below the other, as you can see when the frame is removed.

title: The Sunray Illusion
summary: When presented with intersecting ring-like shapes, most people see bright rays coming from the center, akin to what they would see when looking at the sun breaking through the clouds. However, these shimmering rays are entirely illusory—they are not actually there. The tendency to perceive illusory rays is stronger if there are more intersection points in these shapes and if they are better aligned, allowing our brains to “connect the dots,” which produces the rays. Thus, this illusion is one example of our tendency to interpret the information presented to us in the environment in the most plausible fashion.

title: XRAYSCOPE
summary: Casting a light on the surface of the hand, where the contents you see are not necessarily familiar white-colored bones. All you need is just one half-mirror and two lights to brighten two divided spaces as well as your favorite bone-like objects.

title: Transparent Knife Illusion
summary: This is an illusion in which an ordinary knife looks transparent when it is placed in the middle of the tines of a fork.

title: Illusory ‘Misty’ Contours
summary: The primary ‘goal’ of vision is to efficiently identify objects in a scene and organize them into a perceptual 3D space. In real-world scenes, objects occlude other objects in a figure/ground hierarchy, and the visual brain must perceptually complete occluded features.

title: Dual Axis Illusion
summary: This spinning shape appears to defy logic by rotating around both the horizontal and vertical axis at the same time! To make things even more confusing, the direction of rotation is also ambiguous.

title: The Rotating Circles Illusion
summary: With different moving pattern of outside circles, the inner circle looks to move in different ways though its rotation is static.

title: Bodiject Fingers
summary: You will feel your fingers are objects, just like a pen or vegetable stick. This kind of thought experiment enables us to become aware of the fundamental difficulty of detaching ownership from our body voluntarily. “Bodiject Fingers” challenges such a cognitive barrier.

title: Facing-Right Illusion
summary: The object appears to be a bird facing right. Even though we rotate it around a vertical axis by 180 degrees, we cannot make it to face left; it turns to the right again. The object is made of hard material, but it appears as if it is deforming continuously during rotation. Mathematically a line-symmetric structure in a 3D space is invariant to 180-degree rotation around the line of symmetry. The object is designed using this mathematical property together with the human preference of a familiar silhouette to an actual 3D shape.

title: Helix Rotation
summary: The dots look like a three-dimensional helix. Besides, when the dark filter is over the left eye, the helix rotates clockwise; when the filter is over the right eye, the helix rotates counterclockwise. Moreover, when the viewer uses no filter but blurs the image by squinting both eyes or by using a defocusing lens, motion is upwards for one helix and downwards for the other.

title: 3D Graffiti
summary: There is a 3D graffiti of the Necker cube, a simple wire-frame drawing of a cube with no visual cues as to its orientation.

title: Magic Tic-Tac-Toe
summary: This 3×3 grid show that our sensibility to color brightness can be easily fooled.

title: The Chunder Thunder Illusion
summary: In this illusion, the 17th Dutch marine artist Ludolf Bakhuizen’s painting “Ships on a Stormy Sea” is seemingly bought to life. The ship appears to be tossed around on a raging sea in a wild storm where the waves surge past and the clouds scud across the sky. With the hatches battened down, the crew are experiencing a roller coaster ride! However, this impression of wild motion is illusory.

title: Triply Ambiguous Object
summary: The object generates three different interpretations when it is seen from three special viewpoints. Most of existing ambiguous pictures/objects, such as Necker cube and Schroeder staircase, generate only two interpretations. The present object consists of a 2D picture of a rectangular structure and a pole with a flag. The picture is placed on a horizontal surface and it is seen in slanted directions so that one group of parallel lines appears to be vertical. Then we perceive three different structures because they are compressed in different directions. The pole with a flag represents the direction of the gravity, which strengthens the illusion.

title: Movement Illusion with a Twist
summary: With different patterns or backgrounds, one may see different type of motion.

title: Danswing Papers
summary: The luminance contrast between static “real” objects and a dynamic luminance background causes drastic motion illusions in the objects.

title: The Squish Squash Illusion
summary: When an object is briefly flashed on or near a moving texture, it appears displaced. When the object is flashed on an expanding or contracting texture, it also appears to change shape, expanding or contracting with the background.

title: White + Gray = Red
summary: The grey line in white background looks reddish.

title: Who’s Chasing Whom?
summary: Changing only the background motion of a scene is powerful enough to reverse the perception of who’s chasing whom — from A chasing B, to B chasing A!

title: Just A Tree in Wintertime
summary: This illusion is a photo-based tilt illusion. Some people may think the size of the photos in each row increases in one direction, but that is an illusion. In fact, the lines between the photos are horizontal. This spectacular illusion is caused by: 1) The slight tilt angle of the horizon as well as the trees and 2) The alternation of high contrasting, mirrored photos. This is the first tilt illusion based on a photo grid. The illusion disappears when the red lines are placed. This illusion was discovered by serendipity.

title: Sequin Illusion
summary: The Sequin Illusion can be seen when shapes are drawn in dotted lines, against a background of different brightness. You will see some dark spots inside the shapes

title: Simultaneous Color Contrast Illusion
summary: It is said that the inset color is the same but appears to be different.
